title: nbdev-hello-world
text: This file will become your README and also the index of your documentation.

title: nbdev-hello-world
text:
Developer Guide
If you are new to using nbdev here are some useful pointers to get you started.

Install nbdev_hello_world in Development mode
# make sure nbdev_hello_world package is installed in development mode
$ pip install -e .

# make changes under nbs/ directory
# ...

# compile to have changes apply to nbdev_hello_world
$ nbdev_prepare

title: nbdev-hello-world
text:
Usage

Installation
Install latest from the GitHub repository:
$ pip install git+https://github.com/go-yohan/nbdev-hello-world.git
or from conda
$ conda install -c go-yohan nbdev_hello_world
or from pypi
$ pip install nbdev_hello_world


Documentation
Documentation can be found hosted on this GitHub repository’s pages. Additionally you can find package manager specific guidelines on conda and pypi respectively.

title: nbdev-hello-world
text:
How to use
Fill me in please! Don’t forget code examples:

1+1

2

title: core
text:
source

say_hello

 say_hello (to)

Say hello to somebody

say_hello("Isaac")

'Hello Isaac!'


assert say_hello(“Hammel”) == “Hello Hammel!”

from fastcore.test import *
test_eq(say_hello("Hammel"), "Hello Hammel!")


from IPython.display import display, SVG
display(SVG('<svg height="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle cx="50" cy="50" r="40" /></svg>'))









from nbdev.test import nbdev_test


source


foo

 foo ()


source


HelloSayer

 HelloSayer (to)

Say hello to to using say_hello. This version is displayed inline: \(\sum_{i=1}^{k+1}i\) . You can include text before and after.

o = HelloSayer("Alexis")
o.say()

'Hello Alexis!'
